intro: Alkekengi procumbens, commonly known as the creeping false autumn crocus, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to parts of Europe and western Asia. It belongs to the family Liliaceae and is characterized by its basal rosette of broad, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces showy, bell-shaped flowers that are typically orange or yellow in color, which bloom in late summer to early autumn. Its fruit is a three-lobed, red or orange capsule that splits open to release seeds. Alkekengi procumbens is often found in grasslands, woodland edges, and disturbed soils, and it has ornamental value due to its distinctive foliage and flowers.
